Award.AwardTitle: Biomechanics of Amyloid Oligomer-Induced Stress on Cardiomyocytes

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1133339
Despa

The amyloid oligomers are sticky molecules that attach to cellular membranes and change their mechanical and electrical properties, thus generating molecular forces that can alter cellular signal transduction, function and viability. Despite sustained research efforts, the biomechanics of amyloid oligomer-cell interaction remains elusive. The major goal of this project is to assess the biomechanics of the interaction of islet amyloid polypeptide (IAPP) oligomers with cardiac myocytes, the beating heart cells. IAPP oligomers form within pancreatic â-cells in patients with obesity and type-2 diabetes and are then released in the blood along with insulin. They can deposit locally in pancreatic islets and also in peripheral organs, including the heart. Cardiac accumulation of IAPP amyloids contributes to the development of heart dysfunction, the number one killer in obesity and diabetes. Due to the complex nature of the molecular forces acting at the IAPP oligomer-cardiac myocyte interface, various interaction modes and cellular responses can be expected. Major questions to be addressed in the proposed research are as follows: (1) do IAPP oligomers a) attach to and grow into fibrils at the sarcolemma, b) create pores or c) enter cardiac myocytes?; (2) what are the effects on the sarcolemmal processes?, (3) how they affect contractility and viability of the cardiac myocyte? These questions will be addressed in a multidisciplinary research project that combines biomechanical principles and methods with modern cell physiology experiments, innovative transgenic animal models and mathematical modeling. Deciphering the molecular and cellular signature of IAPP amyloid oligomers in the heart can have a long-term impact in the diagnosis and treatment of diabetic heart dysfunction, a large and growing epidemic with enormous health care costs and social consequences. The expected results may also represent a significant advancement in studying other generic amyloid oligomer-cell interactions, i.e. Aâ oligomers and polyglutamine oligomers interacting with neurons and astrocytes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Human cardiac myocytes, the beating heart cells, are susceptible to increased biomechanical stress in a number of various conditions associated with aging, obesity, insulin resistance and diabetes. In this research, we integrated engineering and life science principles and methods to elucidate how heart damage in people who are obese or diabetic is linked with myocardial accumulation of amylin, a pancreatic hormone that was previously shown to kill the insulin-producing beta cells. By studying failing hearts of obese and diabetic patients, we discovered molecular aggregates, small fibers and plaques made of amylin in both myocardial interstitial spaces and cardiac cells.

Activities developed in this project led to uncovering the primary structural defect induced by an "amylin stress" in cardiac myocytes and downstream alterations of contractility and viability. In this research, we combined single cell experiments and in vivo heart function monitoring in transgenic animal models. Our studies showed that chronic "amylin stress" negatively affects the cardiovascular system by incorporation of toxic aggregated amylin in blood vessels and cardiac cells. The interaction of aggregated amylin with the myocyte cell membrane leads to myocyte remodeling and altered cardiac rhythm. Thus, the results of our project relates to the fundamental understanding of i) how cardiac myocytes respond mechanically to amylin-induced stress and ii) what may limit the ability of these cells to recover their function after the stress ceases. The outcomes of this innovative interdisciplinary project constitute a basis for developing new treatment strategies for reducing cardiovascular risk in individuals with obesity or diabetes. Hence, our project addressed both an important basic science question  and a pressing biomedical problem.

Through this myocardium-focused project, we created a new field of research that branched off in other labs. Furthermore, deciphering the molecular and cellular signature of the interaction of the heart with aggregated amylin could have a long-term impact in diagnosis and treatment of diabetic heart dysfunction, a large and growing epidemic with enormous health care costs and social consequences. The results may also contribute to increasing the understanding of other generic amyloid-cell interactions, i.e., beta amyloid interacting with neurons and astrocytes in brains of patients with Alzheimer's disease. Hence, the contributed work may significantly impact other related research in the field of cellular biomechanics.

Education activities developed during this award included a Freshman Research Seminar "What keeps a cell alive?" at the University of California, Davis (2011-2013) and a course for undergraduate students in the Honors Program at the University of Kentucky focused on "Cell Injury and Disease in Humans". More than 20 students benefited of training in our lab. Lab activities provided students a glimpse into forces and interactions occurring in biological cells, basic concepts from biophysics, chemistry and biology and what mechanisms that keep the cells alive or promote apoptosis and death of cells.
